case_vignette: A 55-year-old male was picked up by police in the public library for harassing the patrons and for public nudity. He displayed disorganized speech and believed that the books were the only way to his salvation. Identification was found on the man and his sister was called to provide more information. She described that he recently lost his house and got divorced within the same week although he seemed fine three days ago. The man was sedated with diazepam and chlorpromazine because he was very agitated. His labs returned normal and within three days, he appeared normal, had no recollection of the past several days, and discussed in detail how stressful the past two weeks of his life were. He was discharged the next day.
question: Which  is the most appropriate diagnosis for this male?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling really agitated and confused lately.
Can you tell me your age and sex?
I'm a 55-year-old male.
Have you been experiencing any headaches or visual disturbances?
No, I haven't had any headaches or visual disturbances.
Do you have a history of high blood pressure or diabetes?
I don't have a history of high blood pressure or diabetes.
Do you take any medications or have any other medical conditions?
I don't take any medications and don't have any other medical conditions that I'm aware of.
Is there any family history of neurological conditions such as dementia or Alzheimer's disease?
There's no mention of a family history of neurological conditions like dementia or Alzheimer's disease.
**Final Diagnosis:** Acute delirium due to an underlying medical condition or infection
